author: BILL ORAM
title: LAKERS: Bryant won't play in Saturday's exhibition
text:
By BILL ORAM / STAFF WRITER
Published: Oct. 16, 2015 Updated: 10:41 p.m. EL SEGUNDO – Fans shell out a lot of money to see Kobe Bryant play, and the Lakers star has long maintained that he has an obligation not to let them down.
“It’s definitely my responsibility to step out there and play,” he said in the first days of training camp in Hawaii.
But Bryant’s desire to perform and the realities of his age and fragility are likely to be regularly at odds in his 20th season.
Saturday’s game against the defending champion Golden State Warriors in San Diego will mark the first instance of the young season.
Bryant, 37, did not practice the past two days while nursing a bruised calf and will not play against the Warriors.
“I think if it was a regular season game there would be a much better chance of him playing,” Coach Byron Scott said Friday. “But since it’s not, there’s no reason for him to play tomorrow night.”
The decision is more about the long play than any fear that Bryant is not healthy enough to play or risk of aggravating the injury.
Scott said his top priority is getting Bryant through the season healthy, and there is no reason to ask him to play through bumps and bruises before the regular season has begun.
“I want him to be as close to 100 as possible” when the regular season starts, Scott said.
Bryant’s absence Saturday sets the table for a team run primarily by its young stars. Jordan Clarkson, Julius Randle and D’Angelo Russell all figure to lead the roster into the future, but this year they must defer somewhat to Bryant.
They insisted Friday that little will change without Bryant on the court, however.
“It’s the same whether he’s out there or not out there,” Randle said. “Dudes are making basketball plays, being aggressive, making the right play.”
Clarkson said the intensity “definitely turns up when (Bryant) steps on the court.”
Scott said Bryant will receive treatment from team trainers Saturday morning but would not travel with the team to San Diego.
Bryant averaged 13 points in 18.2 minutes in the first five preseason games. Russell said the rest of the Lakers might need to be more aggressive offensively to make up for Bryant’s absence.
